intro: Acaena tenera subsp. epilis, commonly known as the slender burr bush, is a shrub native to New Zealand. It is characterized by its small, spiny fruits that contain seeds, typical of the genus Acaena. The plant has narrow, leathery leaves and produces yellow flowers during the spring and summer months. It thrives in coastal and subalpine environments, often growing in sandy or gravelly soils. This subspecies is noted for its ecological importance, providing food for native birds and insects.
distribution_native_art_desc: Acaena tenera subsp. epilis is primarily native to New Zealand. It is found in the South Island, particularly in the eastern and southern regions. This subspecies grows in a variety of habitats, including grasslands, shrublands, and rocky areas. It is commonly associated with coastal and inland environments. The plant is well adapted to the temperate climate of New Zealand.
distribution_introduced_art_desc: Acaena tenera subsp. epilis was mainly introduced to New Zealand. It was brought there as part of the European flora during the colonial period. This plant is now considered a naturalized species in various regions of the country. It has adapted well to the local climate and soil conditions. However, it is not considered invasive and does not pose a significant threat to native ecosystems.
